title: Who were Europe's last pagans?
description:
00:00 - Introduction
00:51 - Who were the last Greco-Roman pagans?
07:49 - What was Europe's last pagan state?
14:15 - Who were the very last pagans in Europe?
21:50 - Conclusion

Who were the last polytheists in Europe, who clung on latest to worshipping the old gods before Christianity conquered the continent?

I approach this question in three different ways.

First we explore the first Greco-Roman pagans, the last worshippers of those gods who so deeply defined classical civilization. The last of these pagans were incredibly late, and far later than I had anticipated.

Then we go to the dark forests and frozen lakes of the Baltic to investigate Europe's last pagan state, a sprawling medieval empire which ultimately triumphed over its Christian foes.

Finally we investigate the last polytheists of all, a journey which will take us to a frozen land of craggy peaks and reindeer herds, punctuated by chanting under the midnight sun.

This video is a great starting point for exploring the forgotten religious diversity of the great European continent.

Sources


Classical paganism

Catherine Nixey, The Darkening Age: The Christian Destruction of the Classical World

Mani pagans - Romily J H. Jenkins (trans.), Constantine VII, De administrando imperio , p. 50, https://archive.org/details/deadministrandoi0000cons/page/236/mode/2up

title: What do we know about the pyramid builders?
description:
00:00 - Introduction
00:46 - Netjerikhet / Djoser and Imhotep and their step pyramid at Saqqara
03:56 - Sneferu's slip-ups - the Meidum Pyramid, the Bent Pyramid, the Red Pyramid
08:04 - Khufu, Hemiunu, the Great Pyramid of Giza, and the workmen's village of Gerget Khufu
12:32 - The Decline of the Pyramid Age: Khafre, Unas and the Pyramid Texts
15:13 - Conclusion

For centuries, people have asked: who really built the pyramids?

Were they the work of lost technologies, superhuman engineers‚Ä¶ or even aliens?

In this video, we explore the real human story behind the Great Pyramids of Egypt. It's a story of trial and error, ambition, mistakes, problem-solving, and thousands of ordinary people whose lives shaped one of history‚Äôs greatest monuments.

In part to debunk whacky conspiracy theories, this video looks at the actual evidence left behind by the pyramid builders themselves.

Such evidence includes everything from statues of architects, food scraps from the worker's village, the state of workmen's bones and the many failed attempts and botch-jobs littered throughout the pyramids' history.

We‚Äôll follow the journey from Djoser‚Äôs first step pyramid, through Sneferu‚Äôs three chaotic attempts ‚Äî the Meidum pyramid, the Bent Pyramid, and finally the Red Pyramid ‚Äî and see how their mistakes paved the way for Khufu‚Äôs Great Pyramid. These monuments weren‚Äôt built by aliens or lost civilizations, but by thousands of skilled artisans, labourers, farmers, overseers, quarry workers, cooks, brewers, and administrators working together.

The pyramids endure not because they were made by perfect beings, but because they were made by humans: determined, ambitious, and sometimes hilariously flawed.

If you‚Äôre curious about:
‚Äì how the pyramids were really built
‚Äì what life was like for the workers
‚Äì why the Egyptians changed from step pyramids to true pyramids
‚Äì what the Old Kingdom kings were really like
‚Äì or the human side of ancient Egypt‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶this video is for you.

#ancienthistory #ancientegypt #egypt #history #archaeology

title: Why the World‚Äôs Oldest Song Still Speaks to Us
description:
My video on ancient Egyptian skepticism - https://youtu.be/h3iZduuAhxs?si=e2Sj3B8WgQNn5IGB

What if you could hear the ancient world?

In this video we explore the world‚Äôs oldest complete song, The Seikilos Epitaph, written almost 2,000 years ago in ancient Greece.

This short but haunting melody, carved into stone, is the earliest piece of music from the ancient world that we can still play exactly as it was written.

Join me as we uncover:

The discovery of the Seikilos Epitaph in modern-day Turkey
The meaning of its lyrics: ‚ÄúAs long as you live, shine‚Ä¶‚Äù
What it reveals about life, death, and philosophy in the ancient world
Why its message still resonates after two millennia

The Seikilos Epitaph is more than just archaeology; it‚Äôs a direct voice from antiquity reminding us to live fully and cherish our brief time.

If you love ancient history, Greek culture, archaeology, or early music, this is for you.

title: A Babylonian Existential Crisis

Even Mesopotamians dealt with meaninglessness some 3000+ years ago.

#Babylon #mesopotamia #ancienthistory #history #existentialism

title: The First Existential Crisis - The Dialogue of Pessimism
description:
Introduction 00:00
Pessimistic interpretation 00:38
Satirical interpretation 2:24
The meaning of life: Ludlul Bel Nemeqi 04:25
Camus, The Myth of Sisyphus and Absurdism 06:12

Have you ever felt like life has no meaning?

You‚Äôre not alone; the Babylonians were wrestling with the same problem over 3,000 years ago.

This video explores The Dialogue of Pessimism, a fascinating Babylonian text which is arguably  first existential crisis in history. In this strange and witty dialogue between a master and his servant, every course of action is proposed and then rejected, leaving death as the only solution.

But is the text really about despair or is it a satire on power, inequality, and contradictory wisdom?

Along the way we‚Äôll uncover:

The Babylonian roots of existential thought

Parallels with the Book of Job and Mesopotamian wisdom literature (Ludlul bel Nemeqi)

Connections to modern philosophy, especially Albert Camus and The Myth of Sisyphus

Does the Dialogue of Pessimism contain the world‚Äôs earliest philosophy of meaninglessness  or the world‚Äôs first dark comedy? Let‚Äôs find out.

If you enjoy exploring ancient history and philosophy then subscribe for more deep dives into the deep past.

#Mesopotamia #Babylon #Existentialism #Philosophy #history #ancienthistory 

Sources

Camus, A. (1942) The Myth of Sisyphus. 

Lenzi, A., Translation of Ludlul Bel Nemeqi, (2019) accessible at https://scholarlycommons.pacific.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1189&context=cop-facbooks

title: This fossil changed the world - and still can.
description:
00:00: Introduction
01:04 Australopithecus africanus
02:36 Piltdown Man and The Taung Child controversy
04:38 The curse of anthropocentrism
07:33 We are animals
10:26 Conclusion

100 years ago, the discovery of the Taung Child fossil in South Africa shattered everything scientists thought they knew about human evolution. Far from the ‚Äúbig-brained European ancestor‚Äù of Piltdown Man, this tiny skull revealed that humanity‚Äôs roots were far more humble - and far more African.

The Taung Child (Australopithecus africanus) walked upright, had a small brain, and died at the talons of an eagle. Its discovery forced us to rethink what it means to be human, and even today, we are still grappling with its implications.

Alongside the Makapansgat pebble, a 3-million-year-old stone carried by Australopithecus because it looked like a face, the Taung fossil shows us that the line between ‚Äúhuman‚Äù and ‚Äúanimal‚Äù is far blurrier than we once believed.

This video explores the story of the Taung Child, the Piltdown hoax, and how these fossils continue to challenge our assumptions about intelligence, sentience, and the kinship we share with the rest of the animal kingdom.

If we truly absorb the lessons of the Taung Child, it might just change how we see the world, and how we treat the animals we share it with.

title: India protected animals - Greece didn‚Äôt. Why?
description:
00:00 Introduction
01:25 Animal sacrifice and the common origins of ancient Greek and Indian culture
03:01 The backlash -  Pythagoras, Buddha and the ≈õrama·πáas
06:30 The difference between ancient Greek and Indian morality
08:33 Comparing the institutions of Pythagoreanism and Buddhism
12:23 Political patronage - Constantine and Ashoka
15:59 Conclusion - One hundred billion coughs

India and Greece - two titans of the ancient world, two wellsprings of art, philosophy and religion. Yet India is world famous, to this day, for its compassion towards animals, while ancient Greece is famed for mass slaughter and sacrifice. Why? What made India different?

Join me as we delve into a secret history of cave-dwelling mystery cults, compassionate mass movements and world-spanning empires as we get to the heart of how social change happens.

Learn how two figures from the 6th century BC - Buddha and Pythagoras - might hold the keys of how we can build a better world today.

For those who are interested in social history, animal rights or simply making the world a better place, this video is for you.

title: The First Honest Politician (And His Fate)
description:
00:00 Introduction
01:00 Context - Early Dynastic Mesopotamia

05:44 Why did Urukagina carry out his reforms?

Let's travel back four and a half thousand years, to the ancient land of Sumer, in the Early Dynastic period.

Here, in the city of Lagash, for a short while, reigned a man who could be called the first honest politician in history: Urukagina.

In a time of widespread disillusion with politics, what can we learn about this amazing reforming king from ancient Mesopotamia. And was Urukagina really as enlightened as is often claimed, or was there a dark side to his rule?

title: The Grumpiest Man in Ancient Egypt
description:
The Heqanakht papyrus provide an amazing window into the ancient world.

But why was the Middle Kingdom so pessimistic? Check out my latest YT video to find out, YT @TheLiberator2020

#ancientegypt #ancienthistory #history #historyfacts #archaeology

title: When the pharaohs stopped smiling
description:
00:00 Introduction
01:08 What was The Old Kingdom like?
02:08 Object analysis - Khafre Enthroned
03:33 The First Intermediate Period
06:17 The early Middle Kingdom
07:51 Senusret III and his miserable statues
08:51 A twist in the tale.
14:07 Conclusion: ma'at and isfet, order and chaos

In the space of a few hundred years, the pharaohs of ancient Egypt went from depicting themselves as youthful, powerful and smiling to grim, careworn and scowling.

I want to find out why.

Why did pharaohs go from showing themselves as youthful and tranquil in the Old Kingdom, to world-weary and grave in the Middle Kingdom?

Do these Middle Kingdom statues symbolise the king as a careworn shepherd of his people?

Or do they suggest something altogether darker?

Answering this question will take us on a journey through extremes - chaos and order, optimism and cynicism, control and collapse.

And we might just learn something about the nature of power itself.

We will look at the history of ancient Egypt‚Äôs Old Kingdom, First Intermediate Period and Middle Kingdom, zoning in on styles of sculpture and key figures like Khafre, Pepi II and Senusret III.

And our conclusion will peer into darkest wells of human nature.

description:

Do check out my latest video to find out how the most beautiful prehistoric pottery in the world was utterly ruined by the birth of civilisation.

#history #mesopotamia #astrology #ancienthistory #archaeology

title: How Civilization Ruined Pottery
description:
00:00 Introduction
00:53 Halaf culture
01:47 Samarran culture
04:14 Ubaid period
07:54 Uruk
12:10 Conclusion

We often like to see civilisation as progress, that things are, however steadily, and with however many set backs, are getting better.

However, the birth of civilisation in Southern Mesopotamia in the fourth millennium BC led to a strange thing - the stunning pots of the Halaf, Samarran and to a lesser extent Ubaid cultures, were replaced with the most appallingly ugly ceramics imaginable.

In this video, I am on a mission to find out why.

Why did prehistoric people make such beautiful pottery? What does that tell us about their society? And how did society change in the build up to the coming of civilization in the Uruk period, one of the most decisive periods in the entirety of human history.

This is a journey that will take us from the savannahs of prehistory, to the buzzing salt-marshes of the Sumerian Gulf Coast to the furnaces and work-gangs of the world's first great city, Uruk.

 In learning about the invention of ugliness, we will not only deepen our knowledge of history, but reflect on the appearance of the modern world.

This isn't one to miss!

Sources

Grossman and Hindman, 'Rethinking Halaf and Ubaid Animal Economies - Hunting and Herding at Tell Zeidan (Syria)', https://www.persee.fr/doc/paleo_0153-9345_2013_num_39_2_5528

title: Who was Egypt‚Äôs Greatest Pharaoh?
description:
00:00 - Cleopatra's Needle and Thutmose III
00:56 - The people who shaped Thutmose III - Thutmose I and Hatshepsut.
03:15 - The Battle of Megiddo and the birth of military history.
08:49 - The Mitanni campaign - Thutmose III crosses the Euphrates.
10:41 - Multiculturalism and empire - Thutmose III as a statesman.
11:53 - Behind the propaganda - an ugly man with stepmom issues?
14:29 - Threading Cleopatra's Needle - what can Thutmose III teach us about power itself?

Who was the greatest pharaoh of all time? Ancient Egypt saw hundreds of different rulers over its extraordinary history, but none were as great as the 18th dynasty's Thutmose III. Rameses II, eat your heart out.

Thutmose III was a fighter, a leader, a conqueror. He was probably the most important and foundational figures of Egypt's New Kingdom, the Egyptian Empire. One of his many extraordinary obelisks stands in London, erroneously called Cleopatra's Needle; a sign that future empires have tried to borrow from this pharaoh's mystique.

In this video I discuss -

The people who shaped Thutmose III - Thutmose I and Hatshepsut.
The Battle of Megiddo and the earliest detailed battle account in history.
Thutmose III's campaign against Mitanni and his elephant hunts at the Euphrates.
The personal charisma and strategic genius of Thutmose III
His flaws, including his strained relationship with his stepmother Hatshepsut.
And finally, what Thutmose III's reign can tell us about the nature of power itself.

I hope you like the video, comment yoru thoughts and subscribe for more tales from the Bronze Age.

Sources

Wilkinson, Toby, Writings from Ancient Egypt, 2016.
Wikinson, Toby, The Rise and Fall of Ancient Egypt, 2010.

#history #ancientegypt #pharaoh #ancient #archaeology

title: A Bronze Age Hindu Kingdom in‚Ä¶ Syria?

The Conference of the Birds is a life changing, amazing poem which is still relatively unknown in the Western world. While of course it is a classic in its home country of Iran / Persia, the rest of the world desperately needs to catch up with this masterpiece of spirituality in Islam.

Of course, this is one of the great works of Sufi literature. The depth of the poem's wisdom and spiritual profundity needs to be read to be believed. In this video we explore Attar of Nishapur‚Äôs biography, before diving into the Man·π≠iq-u·π≠-·π¨ayr, The Conference of the Birds, his masterpiece.

We explore the key themes of the poem including destroying the ego, Attar‚Äôs commitment to love on the Sufi path, and the unity of being.

I hope you leave this video with a deep appreciation of this work, and of Sufism as a creed and Attar as a poet. Do comment, like and subscribe to the channel for more history.

title: The Mysterious Beast of Persepolis
description:
In the heart of the Persian Empire, the stunning ruins of Persepolis reveal a puzzling carving. A group of curly-haired African men approaches King Xerxes I, bearing tribute including an exotic animal. But what is this creature? With its long neck, ridged mane, and small horns, scholars have debated its identity for years.

Could it be a giraffe? A nilgai from India? Or, in a truly mind-blowing twist, could it be a stunning and extremely rare creature from the forests of Central Africa...

In this video, we dive into the interconnected ancient world, exploring the vast Achaemenid Persian Empire, trade routes stretching from Egypt to India, and the fascinating role of exotic animals in ancient courts.

Chapters:
0:00 - The Strange Carving at Persepolis
01:08 - Ancient Persia - the most underrated civilisation
03:19 - Possible Animal Candidates: Giraffe, Nilgai, or Okapi?
09:35 - The Astonishing Implications of an Okapi in Persia.

Was Persia more advanced than Greece?
Unlike the way Hollywood depicts the Persian Empire (think 300's weird mutant hordes), history tells a different story. The Persians ruled the largest empire the world had ever seen, stretching from the Balkans to India, with sophisticated infrastructure, art, and trade networks.

The Okapi Theory: An Impossible Journey?
The okapi, a secretive giraffe relative from the Congo rainforest, was unknown to the Western world until 1901. But could it have made its way to 5th century BC Persepolis? The evidence is tantalizing.

What does this tell us?
This ancient mystery highlights the astonishing global connections of the past. From the rainforests of Africa to the palaces of Iran, the ancient world was far more interconnected than we often imagine.

Join the discussion! What do YOU think this animal was? Leave a comment below.

Like, subscribe & share if you love ancient mysteries, forgotten history, and mind-blowing archaeology!

#Persepolis #PersianEmpire #AncientMystery #Okapi #Giraffe #Archaeology #ancienthistory #Persia #Xerxes #history #MysteryBeast

Sources
Burton, Adrian. ‚ÄúThe Okapi‚Äôs Missing Stripes.‚Äù Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment, vol. 19, no. 1, 2021, p. 76. JSTOR, https://www.jstor.org/stable/26986383. Accessed 21 Mar. 2025.

title: Did ancient Egyptians doubt their religion?
description:
I have an ancient Egyptian name for Christopher Hitchens in the main video on YT‚Ä¶ :-)

Ancient people could be critical thinkers and skeptics too and not everyone in ancient Egypt easily believed in an afterlife.

#ancientegypt #egyptology #ancient #religion #mythology

title: Did Ancient Egyptians Doubt Their Religion? (Evidence of Ancient atheism)
description:
00:00 Introduction
00:46 Background to the Harpist's Song of King Intef
01:33 Why was Middle Kingdom literature skeptical?
03:57 The Harpist's Song of King Intef
07:46 A dialogue between a man and his ba
11:18 Ozymandias
13:41 Conclusion

We often visualise Ancient Egypt as deeply religious civilization, obsessed with the afterlife. They created pyramids, mummies, and elaborate burial rites all designed to secure eternal life. But did Ancient Egyptians doubt their own religion? Did they question the existence of an afterlife they could not see, hear, or touch?

The answer is a resounding YES.

In this video, we uncover two astonishing texts that prove ancient skepticism existed over 4,000 years ago. These texts challenge the idea that all Egyptians blindly believed in the afterlife, revealing a YOLO philosophy, which feels startlingly modern.

We will discuss -

The Harpist‚Äôs Song from the Tomb of King Intef - A Middle Kingdom lyric that dismisses the certainty of an afterlife and encourages people to enjoy life while they can.
 
A Dialogue Between a Man and His Ba - A heart-wrenching debate between a man and his soul, where the man longs for death, but his soul warns him that the afterlife may not be what he expects.

These texts challenge the traditional image of Ancient Egypt as a land of unwavering faith. Just as in today‚Äôs world, people in ancient times grappled with doubt, fear, and the uncertainty of what happens after death.

Join us as we explore history‚Äôs earliest skeptics and uncover how their words still resonate today.

Subscribe for more deep dives into ancient history, religion, and philosophy!

If you enjoyed this video, give it a like and share your thoughts in the comments.

Sources

Toby Wilkinson, Writings from Ancient Egypt

#AncientEgypt #History #Skepticism #Atheism #EgyptianMythology #Afterlife #Philosophy #Religion

title: After the Apocalypse: What Anglo-Saxons thought of Roman Britain
description:
What did the Anglo-Saxons think of the Romans? This video dives into the relationship between Roman Britain and the Anglo-Saxon era, exploring ancient ruins, Old English poetry, and the echoes of an empire long gone.

When we imagine Roman times in Britain, we think of grandeur‚Äîheated bathhouses, mighty legions, and sophisticated cities. But after Rome‚Äôs fall, the Anglo-Saxons inherited a land of crumbling ruins. How did they interpret the vast, abandoned Roman baths and towering stone structures that dwarfed their wooden mead halls?

This question is beautifully answered in The Ruin, an Old English poem from the Exeter Book, which contemplates the decay of Aquae Sulis (modern Bath). Through the lens of this poem, we see how the Saxons both admired and mourned the lost wisdom of Rome.

Key Topics Covered:

The transition from Roman rule to the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms 

How the Saxons preserved and interpreted Roman history and myth

Franks Casket ‚Äì A treasure trove of Latin and Germanic culture

The collapse of Roman civilization and the return to pre-Roman ways

The Ruin ‚Äì A haunting poem about lost empires and the passage of time

Dustceawung ‚Äì The Anglo-Saxon concept of meditating on impermanence

Primary sources
Crossley-Holland, Kevin, The Anglo-Saxon World: An Anthology, Oxford World Classics, 2009.

Secondary Sources

Estes, Heidi, ‚ÄúRuined Landscapes‚Äù in Anglo Saxon Literary Landscapes, https://doi.org/10.2307/j.ctt1zkjxx3.6

The Egyptian Book of the Dead is a masterpiece of the ancient world. A bewildering mix of hymns, spells and hallucinatory visions of the afterlife, it was scribbled down by scribes 3500 years ago during the New Kingdom of Egypt.

title: Charles I final words before the executioner struck
description:
00:00 Introduction
01:02 The background and causes of the English Civil War
07:55 Charles I and the Divine Right of Kings
09:36 The Trial of Charles I
14:16 The Execution of Charles I

The execution of Charles I remains one of the most shocking, surprising, and seismic events in British history‚Äîand history as a whole.

On January 30th, 1649, King Charles I was executed after a fiery and perfunctory trial, marking an unprecedented and deeply unpopular moment. This act, driven by a small group of army officers and Parliamentary radicals, sent shockwaves through the nation and across Europe.

Charles I had led the Royalists through the First and Second English Civil Wars, ultimately paying the price with his life. His reign had been defined by religious tensions, political strife, and bloodshed, culminating in this dramatic and bloody conclusion.

Yet, the most surprising and moving part of the execution of Charles I was after his execution speech, the king‚Äôs actual final words, recorded by the Bishop of London, William Juxon. On that bitterly cold January morning in 1649, Charles' final moments revealed a profound and lasting insight into his character and our innate humanity.

In this video, we explore the significance of Charles I‚Äôs final words, the history surrounding his execution, and how it continues to resonate in the story of the UK and beyond.

Primary Sources

The court proceedings and execution of Charles I - https://quod.lib.umich.edu/e/eebo/A40615.0001.001 

Secondary Sources

title: A Prehistoric Cannibal Massacre
description:
00:00 Charterhouse Warren
03:32 Cannibal Comparisons: Gough Cave
04:43 Herxheim
06:40 Endocannibalism and Exocannibalism
08:00 Why do we find cannibalism so shocking?
09:01 Montaigne, Of Cannibals
09:57 Conclusion: the beauty and the horror

Cannibalism is one of those salacious parts of prehistory that gets everyone talking. On the 16th December 2024, this Monday, news broke of a Somerset Bronze Age massacre from the Mendip Hills. The victims, found in a limestone shaft in a cave system called Charterhouse Warren, reveal one of the most shockingly violent examples of cannibalism in prehistory.

Charterhouse Warren is not unique. 3km away is a much older example of cannibalism, from Gough‚Äôs Cave, where people fashioned human skulls into cups. At a site called Herxheim in Germany, archaeologists unearthed the remains of up to 1000 people hacked up in ditches, their bones bearing clear marks of butchery and cooking.

How do we make sense of this? Why did people practice cannibalism, both in prehistory and history? And what does this say about human nature and ethics?

Join me as we explore all of these questions, and do subscribe for more ruminations about the past.

#archaeology #prehistory #cannibalism #history #bronzeage #historystories

description:
In the West, are we fundamentally Christian or fundamentally human? My full critique of Tom Holland from the Rest is History podcast‚Äôs ideas on Christianity is up now on my channel!

title: Tom Holland is WRONG about Christianity | The Rest is History
description:
Here is my video about human uniqueness -  https://youtu.be/gsEBPf3KRnQ?si=HjZW-JqoLFoqWISO 

00:00 Introduction
03:00 The Argument of Dominion
04:20 Violence
21:38 Christianity and Slavery
33:38 Class and Charity
40:00 Women
46:46 Science
54:08 Is everything Christianity?
58:43 Conclusion

This is the definitive Tom Holland of The Rest is History takedown!

Is Christianity the absolute foundation of Western civilisation, or is Tom Holland mistaken? In this detailed video essay, reviewing Tom Holland‚Äôs acclaimed book Dominion, I explore the deep impact of Christianity on Western and global history while ultimately concluding that Tom overestimates Christianity‚Äôs impact and ingenuity.

Tom Holland, co-host of The Rest is History podcast, makes a strong and thought-provoking case for Christianity being a major revolution, he goes too far. Can Christianity truly be responsible for every major moral and intellectual advance in the West over the last 1700 years?

In this video essay, I explore the history of Christianity through the themes of violence, slavery, charity, women, and science, while drawing comparisons with the planet‚Äôs other great civilisations like the Islamic world, India, and China. I argue that while Christianity has been undeniably influential, compassionate ideologies have flourished in all corners of the globe, and key advances in political equality owe much to the Enlightenment rather than Christianity alone.

Whether you're a fan of The Rest is History, a generic past-oriented boffin or someone exploring the intersection of religion and morality, this video offers a sensationally fair-minded and titillatingly well-written perspective.

Topics Covered:
Christianity and compassion
Comparisons with Indian religions, Islam and Daoism.
The Enlightenment's role in human rights and equality
Christianity and Slavery
A critical take on Dominion by Tom Holland

If you enjoy discussions about history, religion, and philosophy, don‚Äôt forget to like, subscribe, and share your thoughts in the comments!

#tomholland #therestishistory #christianity #history #videoessay #philosophy #religion #slavery

description:

This is the second part of a two part investigation of Herodotus‚Äô account of ancient Egypt. Part one is here - https://youtu.be/AaIVpXGHYmA?si=3Dcu5alusilbdgkJ 

Who knew that Ancient Egypt could be so funny and profound? Today we explore how Herodotus‚Äô Histories gives us an extraordinary portrayal of the japester pharaoh Amasis II, and fills us with joy at many humorous stories from ancient Egyptian history and folklore.

As well as having a good belly laugh, we also explore the more wise, touching and insightful stories from Herodotus, including his thoughts on iconic landmarks like the Labyrinth and pyramids, as well as the incredible fact that he has access to information that stretches from Russia to the Congo.

It is bracing deep-dive into ancient Egyptian culture, history and religion and I hope you enjoy watching it as much as I enjoyed making it.

Sources
Herodotus, The Histories, trans. Robin Waterfield, Oxford's World Classics, 2008

title: The World's Oldest Wisdom: The Library of Ashurbanipal
description:
00:00 The Library of Ashurbanipal
02:14 Why look at Mesopotamian proverbs?
03:12 Were Mesopotamians similar to us?
03:28 The character of Ashurbanipal
04:23 Mesopotamian religion and underworld
05:31 Mesopotamian proverbs
06:12 The smith's dog could not overturn the anvil; he therefore overturned the waterpot instead.
07:01 Upon escaping from the wild ox, the wild cow confronted me.
07:55 You don't speak of that which you have found. You speak only of what you have lost.
09:02 No one walks for a second time at the place where a lion has eaten a man.
10:52 A dog said to his master: "If my pleasure is of no importance to you, then my loss should not be either."
11:23 Tell a lie and then tell the truth; it will be heard as a lie.
12:38 Fate is a dog walking always behind a man.
13:05 A dog which is played with turns into a puppy.
14:03 Conclusion

Mesopotamia, the land of the two rivers, is the font of civilization. Here is where writing itself, the ability to convey information over miles and millennia, was invented, where monumental ziggurats were raised out of mud and clay, and where kings and councillors politicked and prayed while much of the rest of the world were hurling rocks at one another.

(I jest, Stone Age hunter gatherers were actually very cool and sophisticated.)

Arguably the apogee of Mesopotamian culture and power comes with the Assyrians (the study of Mesopotamia is called Assyriology after all), and no Assyrian monarch was more formidable or learned than Ashurbanipal.

The Library of Ashurbanipal was one of his crowning achievements, dug out of modern Mosul in the 19th century, containing tens of thousands of cuneiform texts rich with myths like the Epic of Gilgamesh, which changed our understanding of the Bible for good.

But, most interesting to me, are the collections of Mesopotamian proverbs unearthed from the Library of Ashurbanipal, which are so relatable and resonant with the modern day. These truly do represent the oldest wisdom in world history.

I hope you like this video and consider subscribing and supporting the channel, thanks!


Sources

Mark, Joshua J, Ashurbanipal‚Äôs Collection of Sumerian and Babylonian proverbs. World History Encyclopedia, https://www.worldhistory.org/article/181/ashurbanipals-collection-of-sumerian-and-babylonia/

title: What Was Life in Ancient Egypt Like? Herodotus on Ancient Egypt
description:
00:00 Introduction to Herodotus and Histories
01:24 How much should Herodotus be trusted?
02:30 The bizarre in Ancient Egyptian culture.
03:00 Animals in Ancient Egypt
04:26 Animal mummies and religion of Ancient Egyptian Late Period.

14:19 The Disgusting

15:05 The bodies of beautiful women
15:42 Why Ancient Egyptian perverts are interesting
16:17 "Pheros", Nature and urine.
17:49 The sons of Phases and some light cannibalism.
18:56 Conclusion and teaser for part two

Part One! Part Two coming soon...

What was Ancient Egypt like? It can be hard to know sometimes, as so many Ancient Egyptian sources are focused on the conquests of pharaohs or religious and funerary rituals. What about daily life? Folk customs and culture?

Enter Herodotus, one of the most fascinating, shocking, outrageous and hilarious sources on Ancient Egypt, but also one of the best. Ancient Egyptian history would not be the same without Herodotus‚Äô marvellous Histories - he isn‚Äôt called the Father of History for nothing. Herodotus gives us insights into Ancient Egyptian civilisation like no other.

What he wrote about, from Ancient Egyptian religion, to festivals, battles, myths, daily life and customs, will make your jaw drop for its bizarreness and the immense colour with which he describes this long-dead civilisation. By untangling Ancient Egypt‚Äôs mysteries, secrets and obscurities, perhaps we can come to better understand our culture too.

Herodotus and Ancient Egyptian culture are unpacked here by Matthew Chalmers, of The Liberator Youtube channel, who received a masters degree in Egyptology from the University of Cambridge and is passionate about history, philosophy and culture. 

Please like, comment and subscribe, especially to get your hands on Part Two.

title: A Mysterious Minoan Masterpiece - The Pylos Combat Agate.
description:
00:00 Introduction
00:55 Homeric Pylos and the Bronze Age Palace
02:35 The Tomb of the Griffin Warrior
02:50 Who was the Griffin Warrior?
04:17 What is the Pylos Combat Agate?
05:07 The details on the Pylos Combat Agate
06:20 How did ancient Minoans make the Pylos Combat Agate?
07:48 Where was the Pylos Combat Agate made?
08:18 What is the relationship between the Minoans and Mycenaeans?
09:31 Analysis of the iconography of the Pylos Combat Agate
10:35 Does it depict a scene from the Iliad or Trojan War?
13:07 Conclusion

Video on Ancient Egyptian Exploration - https://youtu.be/8u9pLaOY4CM?si=aAM_UMtr80bS5KrB
 
Today we‚Äôre talking about the mysterious ancient Minoan Civilisation of Crete, arguably Europe‚Äôs first true civilisation, possessing monumental architecture, beautiful, serene art, and writing (albeit undeciphered by scholars). 

The Minoan civilisation created sculptors and painters of prodigal talent, a millennium before classical Greece. In fact, the Minoans weren‚Äôt even Greeks, but ancestors of the shadowy Stone Age peoples of the Aegean, and as such their lineage spans back into the dense fog of prehistory.

The gifted craftsmen and artists of Minoan civilisation created many a masterwork. But one, in my opinion, stands above all others - and that‚Äôs the Pylos Combat Agate. A tiny, minute sealstone, a mere 3.6cm long, the level of detail on this object is plainly stunning.

In fact, it's downright mysterious. How was it made, how could such fine details be put into such hard stone 3500 years ago? What tools were used? Was magnification involved? Mystery upon mystery floats around this object - all of it complicated by the fact that it wasn‚Äôt discovered in ancient Minoan Crete at all, but on the Mycenaean Greek mainland, at Pylos. What was the relationships between Minoan and Mycenaean? Was it Minoan vs Mycenaean or were they buddies? We'll also explore the question - is Minoan Greek?

In this video I explore the spellbinding, ancient culture  of the Minoan civilisation through the prism of this extraordinary object. I invite you all to subscribe, and let's get a conversation started in the comments. Much love.

title: Battle of Hastings REMATCH - Normans vs Saxons,  Dyrrhachium 1081.
description:
00:00 - Introduction
01:33 - Context - Southern Italy in the 11th century
02:14 - Norman pilgrims and mercenaries
03:14 - Harald Hardrada
04:19 - Normans were frightening
05:19 - Robert Guiscard

09:27 - England after the Norman Conquest
10:30 - Anglo-Saxons and the Varangian Guard

13:00 - Norman invasion of Balkans
13:45 - Battle of Dyrrhachium
16:13 - Aftermath of the battle
16:31 - A New England in the East?
17:08 - Conclusion

Most of us have heard about The Battle of Hastings 1066, the decisive moment which marked the end of the Anglo-Saxon world and the start of a new, Frenchified, Norman epoch in England. However, what if I told you that Normans and Anglo-Saxons would cross swords again fifteen years later, far from English soil?

The 1066 rematch, in vengeance for Hastings, was to be fought not in the Hastings hills but in the Byzantine Balkans. This is the tale of the Battle of Dyrrhachium in 1081, and the incredible unknown story of what happened to a band of Anglo-Saxons, far from home and from the oppression of Norman castles, afterwards....

title: How Far Did The Ancient Egyptians Explore?
description:
00:00 - Introduction: The Tale of the Shipwrecked Sailor.
05:08 - Harkhuf's Expeditions to Yam: Exploring Deep into Africa.
12:09 - Hatshepsut's Journey to Punt: The Quest for Exotic Treasures.
16:22 - Crete and Keftiu: Ancient Egypt‚Äôs Connection to the Minoan Civilization.
21:42 - Necho II and Phoenician Mariners: Circumnavigating Africa - Fact or Myth?
26:15 - Conclusion - A Magical World, Then and Now.

Explore the incredible journeys of Ancient Egyptian explorers who ventured beyond the Nile's familiar banks into uncharted territories. From the legendary tale of the Shipwrecked Sailor to the daring expeditions to Punt, discover how far the Ancient Egyptians traveled and what they knew about the world beyond their borders. Join me as we delve into fascinating voyages across Africa, the Mediterranean, and beyond, uncovering the true extent of their exploration and the mysteries Ancient Egyptians encountered.

How far did these explorers travel? How much of the world did they truly understand? From the mysterious lands of Yam and Punt to connections with the Minoan civilization in Crete, these are the stories of those who dared to push the boundaries of the known world. Perfect for history buffs and lovers of ancient civilisations, this video unravels the adventurous spirit of Ancient Egypt.

Sources

Kyriakidis, Evangelos, 'Indications on the Nature of the Language of the Keftiw from Egyptian Sources', https://www.researchgate.net/publication/270485625_Indications_on_the_Nature_of_the_Language_of_the_Keftiw_from_Egyptian_Sources

description:

Full video now out on main channel, please like, subscribe and let me know what you think in the comments.

title: Are Humans Just Like Other Animals?
description:
00:00 - Introduction: Understanding Human Uniqueness
00:40 - Ideological Foundations of Anthropocentrism
02:33 - Narlugas: Unveiling Hybrid Species
03:40 - Hybrids and the Limitations of 'Species' Definition
04:20 - Neanderthals: Close Relatives of Homo Sapiens
07:06 - Homo Naledi: Insights into Ancient Hominids
10:21 - Homo Erectus: The Early Human Ancestor
12:23 - Chimpanzees: Our Closest Living Relatives
17:06 - Farmed Animals: Ethical Considerations
19:32 - Homo Sapiens: Only 2.5% of Animal Life
20:28 - Challenging Anthropocentrism: What We Stand to Gain
23:36 - Post-Script: Final Thoughts on Human-Animal Relationships

Dive deep into the world of paleoanthropology and explore what makes humans unique in this comprehensive video. We'll journey through the fascinating connections between Homo sapiens and our hominid cousins, including Neanderthals, Homo naledi, and Homo erectus. We also delve into the concept of anthropocentrism‚Äîwhy humans often view themselves as the pinnacle of evolution‚Äîand challenge this notion by examining our close ties to other species, such as chimpanzees.

As we explore these topics, we highlight the ethical implications for our treatment of animals, particularly in the context of factory farming. With 97.5% of sentient life on Earth being non-human, it's crucial to reconsider our place in the natural world and our responsibility towards other species. Join us in questioning the status quo and consider supporting effective animal charities to combat cruelty in today's food system.

Support animal charities here: https://animalcharityevaluators.org/donate/

Your support = my happiness, thank you dear viewer - https://www.patreon.com/theliberator2020

title: The Cuckoo in Matsuo Bash≈ç‚Äôs Haiku: Exploring Poetry, Zen, and Nature
description:
00:00 - Introduction: Matsuo Bash≈ç and the Cuckoo
00:20 - Who Was Bash≈ç? A Brief Biography

Please consider helping out a small broke Youtuber explore the big topics like cuckoos - nobody is talking about this - https://www.patreon.com/theliberator2020

The cuckoo‚Äôs call has echoed through poetry across time and cultures, from the haiku of Matsuo Bash≈ç to the verses of Wordsworth. In this video, I explore the significance of the cuckoo in Japanese haiku, especially in the works of Bash≈ç, and compare it with its portrayal in Tang Dynasty poetry, English literature, and beyond.

Join me on this poetic journey as we delve into themes of nature, Zen Buddhism, and cultural symbolism. Whether you're a poetry lover or curious about cultural symbolism, this video offers a deep dive into the art of haiku and the universal resonance of the cuckoo's call.

Sources

title: What did Romans think about Animals?
description:
00:00 - Introduction: Animal Life in Ancient Rome
00:15 - Animals and the Colosseum: Gladiatorial Games
02:27 - Modern-Day Animal Bloodsports
02:54 - Roman Perspectives on Animals
03:09 - Wolves in Roman Culture
03:33 - The Role of Dogs in Roman Society
04:42 - Anthropocentrism in Ancient Rome
05:52 - Lions in the Arena: The Ultimate Symbol of Power
07:38 - Romans Who Opposed Animal Suffering
08:57 - Hypocrisy Then and Now: A Historical Perspective
09:50 - Animal Suffering in Today‚Äôs World
10:30 - Bloodsports vs. Animal Farming: Ethical Considerations
11:35 - When Dying Elephants Made the Roman Mob Cry
13:25 - Conclusion: Reflecting on Animal Rights

When we think of the Romans, gladiatorial games and brutal Colosseum spectacles often come to mind, where countless animals were slaughtered. But was Roman society as heartless towards animals as we imagine? This video explores the nuanced views Romans held towards animals, their involvement in bloodsports, and the unexpected moments of compassion that sometimes surfaced.

We‚Äôll also compare these ancient practices to modern-day animal cruelty and discuss how our attitudes towards animals have‚Äîor haven‚Äôt‚Äîevolved. Please consider supporting the channel through Patreon to help keep these discussions going: https://www.patreon.com/theliberator2020
